2023-10-07T18:27:39Z: Thank you as always for joining us this evening. We'll be back tomorrow to bring you all the action as it unfolds in the Qatar Grand Prix, and if it's anything like tonight then the race promises plenty of excitement - even if the world championship is already decided. We'll see you then. Goodnight!
2023-10-07T18:26:15Z: How do you celebrate clinching a world championship knowing that you've got the full grand prix to come? Untested waters for Verstappen tonight, as he prepares to start tomorrow's full points-paying grand prix from pole with George Russell alongside, and the nearest McLaren back on row three.
2023-10-07T18:24:15Z: So it was Piastri who took the flag first from Verstappen, Norris, Russell, Hamilton and Sainz, with Leclerc and Albon (up from 17th in 19 laps!) completing the points. But Leclerc and Stroll (who finished a nondescript 13th) are being investigated for track limits. We told you that it couldn't be ruled out completely...
2023-10-07T18:22:32Z: The top three drivers are presented with their little plaques for their 'podium' positions. Verstappen is all smiles, and rightly so. Red Bull lost the battle today, but won the war.
2023-10-07T18:20:53Z: In case you missed any of the action from that breathless sprint, here is the full report: https://www.autosport.com/f1/news/f1-qatar-gp-sprint-race/10530052/
2023-10-07T18:19:44Z: Choosing the 'right' compound in the medium, as the slick runners' gamble failed to pay off after an early surge up the order, ultimately helped Piastri's path and aided Norris in his comeback to third. But what can the McLarens do from sixth (Piastri) and tenth (Norris) tomorrow?
2023-10-07T18:17:29Z: It's Verstappen's day, but McLaren has again served notice of its strength in Qatar on an eventful evening that saw three safety cars as Lawson and Sargeant spun off in solo incidents before the Ocon-Hulkenberg-Perez sandwich ended up with the first and last-named in the gravel too.
2023-10-07T18:15:48Z: Red Bull has had plenty of time to get its celebratory champion caps made (presumably not after a visit to the wind tunnel first, though - eh, Adrian?) which are now adorning the heads of some smiling mechanics.
2023-10-07T18:14:43Z: Verstappen also congratulates Piastri, who becomes just the second non-Red Bull driver to cross the line first in a race scenario this year.
2023-10-07T18:13:55Z: FIA President Mohamed ben Sulayem and F1 CEO Stefano Domenicali are among the first to congratulate the newly crowned three-time world champion in parc ferme.
2023-10-07T18:11:38Z: It's the first 'win' for Piastri in F1 and the first for McLaren since Monza 2021. But of course it won't count in the record books given the weird status that sprint races hold. And come tomorrow's grand prix both McLarens will start well down the order thanks to their track limits gaffes in Qualifying on Friday, so may face a struggle to get onto the podium. Funny how F1 works sometimes.
2023-10-07T18:10:45Z: Verstappen sounds very chilled on the radio as he comes to terms with becoming a three-time champion. It's been coming for a while, hasn't it?
2023-10-07T18:09:15Z: Oscar Piastri crosses the line to win the Qatar sprint race, but with second place Max Verstappen is confirmed as a three-time Formula 1 world champion.
2023-10-07T18:08:49Z: Hamilton gets the move done and moves up to fifth.
2023-10-07T18:08:32Z: Hamilton has taken Leclerc for sixth, and Albon demotes Alonso to nab eighth. But Hamilton isn't finished and is applying the pressure on Sainz.
2023-10-07T18:08:00Z: We're on the last lap now, and it looks like Verstappen has run out of time to get back on terms with Piastri.
2023-10-07T18:07:27Z: Hamilton has passed Gasly and immediately pounce on Alonso into Turn 1, as behind Albon displaces Gasly too. Alonso stands between the Williams driver and a point, as Hamilton attacks the Ferraris.
2023-10-07T18:06:16Z: It doesn't take Norris long to complete the move though, and he's through into fourth around the outside of Turn 4.
2023-10-07T18:05:31Z: Leclerc's hold on fifth is brief as Norris darts past on the outside with DRS into Turn 1, then immediately has a peek down the inside of Sainz into Turn 2 before thinking better of it.
2023-10-07T18:04:33Z: Albon meanwhile has passed Bottas for tenth.
2023-10-07T18:04:16Z: He has three laps to make up 2.4s. He'll be world champion as things stand, but will Verstappen seal the deal in style?
2023-10-07T18:03:45Z: As we start lap 16 Verstappen zaps Russell for second down the inside of Turn 1. Can he catch up to Piastri?
2023-10-07T18:02:47Z: Hamilton has also lost a spot to Gasly, who gains eighth spot and the final point as things stand.
2023-10-07T18:02:19Z: We're back to green at the start of lap 15 and as Piastri leads Russell, Leclerc steals fifth back from Norris.
2023-10-07T18:00:21Z: The safety car is coming in, so we'll have four more laps to decide the Qatar sprint race.
2023-10-07T17:58:52Z: So Piastri has the lead then under the third safety car of the night, having blasted back ahead of Russell. Verstappen is looking menacing in third, with Sainz now hoping to fend off a recovering Norris. Leclerc is sixth, with Alonso also on softs in seventh, then Hamilton on the medium, Gasly on the soft and Bottas on the medium in tenth.
2023-10-07T17:57:01Z: Hulkenberg has damage and pits. The carnage at the tail end of the top 10 promotes Hamilton to eighth and the final point as things stand.
2023-10-07T17:56:22Z: Ocon was struggling on his softs and Hulkenberg took a big look to the outside of Turn 1. Perez got alongside both of them with a better exit and as Ocon moved across on Hulkenberg, the pair made contact which cut down the tyre on the Alpine and sent him straight into the luckless Perez.
2023-10-07T17:54:41Z: Norris moves ahead of Leclerc to claim fifth, but we're back under the safety car now as Perez and Ocon are in the gravel. The Red Bull man is not happy with his Alpine counterpart.
2023-10-07T17:53:32Z: Ah, Verstappen passed Leclerc on the previous tour into Turn 1 with a simple DRS blast to the inside. And now Piastri does the same to Russell! The Aussie is back in the lead, and it's as straightforward a pass as he'll ever make.
2023-10-07T17:52:09Z: No sooner had he passed Leclerc, even before we'd managed to clock it, Verstappen makes easy work of Sainz on the pit straight to claim third.
2023-10-07T17:50:35Z: Perez does however pass Gasly and move up into tenth spot, getting the cutback on the exit of Turn 1 before completing the move around the outside of Turn 2. Hulkenberg is his next target.
2023-10-07T17:50:15Z: Perez got shuffled back at the start and remains 11th, ahead of Hamilton. The Mexican's target is Gasly ahead, but 10th won't get him any points today with the sprint only rewarding drivers down to eighth.
2023-10-07T17:49:01Z: Russell is 1.5s clear of Piastri, as the first full racing lap is completed since the start. How much of a gap will he be able to pull before settling into tyre save mode, knowing the McLaren's tyres will be much more durable?
2023-10-07T17:48:18Z: Alonso meanwhile has retaken Ocon for seventh, darting ahead even before the braking zone for Turn 1.
2023-10-07T17:47:12Z: The safety car is in, and Russell leads the field onto lap seven with a well-judged restart. He's 1.4s clear at the line as Piastri has to defend from Sainz into Turn 1.
2023-10-07T17:46:13Z: As we begin lap six under the safety car, Russell leads Piastri after sneaking ahead into the Turn 6 hairpin, with Sainz and Leclerc third and fourth. Verstappen is in position to seal the title despite only running fifth, ahead of Norris, Ocon and Alonso.
2023-10-07T17:43:17Z: Meanwhile, Sainz is worried about a misfire issue in his Ferrari, which he instructs the team to fix or else he will lose third position. The team believes it was a surge issue and considers changing a setting.
2023-10-07T17:42:48Z: Alonso actually lost a place on that restart skirmish. After going wheel to wheel with Norris, he was then ambushed by Ocon who pulls off a superb move around the outside.
2023-10-07T17:41:28Z: The American's run of difficult races continues, and this certainly won't help his cause to keep his seat for next year - with the team pledging it will make its decision only at the end of the season. It certainly will help the soft tyre runners however, as they will get to once again cool their rubber.
2023-10-07T17:40:39Z: But we're back to safety car again as Sargeant as spun his Williams into the boonies.
2023-10-07T17:39:49Z: Immediately Alonso pressurises Norris and the two go wheel-to-wheel, but as the Brit holds on the other McLaren loses the lead as Piastri goes wide and cedes position to Russell.
2023-10-07T17:38:49Z: As we begin lap three we're back to racing!
2023-10-07T17:38:31Z: Sainz ran very wide into Turn 3, which allowed Leclerc alongside him into Turn 4 but the Singapore GP winner ran his team-mate wide over the kerbs to firmly keep hold of his position.
2023-10-07T17:37:38Z: Lawson is out of the car after his visit to the gravel. The replays show his car simply swapped ends on him, a tankslapper spitting him into the gravel.
2023-10-07T17:37:11Z: The soft tyres certainly had their desired effect at the start for Russell and the Ferraris then, with Sainz briefly going three-wide with Russell and Norris into Turn 1. Norris then was mugged into Turn 2 by Verstappen, as the Ferraris scrapped tooth and nail ahead.
2023-10-07T17:35:09Z: Norris and Verstappen were swamped off the line, and there's mayhem further back as Lawson goes off, bringing out the safety car.
2023-10-07T17:34:35Z: We're go in Qatar and it's a great start for Piastri as he leads from the soft-shod Russell and Sainz.
2023-10-07T17:32:47Z: Remember, the distance is 19 laps and there are no mandatory pitstops in the sprint race. Piastri, Norris and Verstappen are all on medium tyres. Who will get to the flag first? Nearly time to find out.
2023-10-07T17:30:56Z: On the tyre front, Russell, Sainz and Leclerc all opt for softs, as do Alonso, Ocon, Gasly, Stroll and Sargeant. Will the gamble pay off?
2023-10-07T17:29:49Z: Engines are fired on the grid as the formation lap is about to begin.
2023-10-07T17:28:18Z: Amid all the talk about tyres, Pirelli is expected to be announced next week as F1's tyre supplier until 2028 after successfully fending off a challenge from Bridgestone: https://www.autosport.com/f1/news/new-pirelli-f1-tyre-deal-to-be-announced-next-week/10530001/
2023-10-07T17:27:05Z: Will this be the race we see Max Verstappen match the world championship tally of Jack Brabham, Jackie Stewart, Nicki Lauda, Nelson Piquet and Ayrton Senna? Remember, he only needs to finish sixth to be crowned for a third time and become the first driver ever to become champion following a sprint race.
2023-10-07T17:25:13Z: Just five minutes to go until we're racing in Qatar.
2023-10-07T17:24:11Z: As drivers clamber into their cockpits, we await to see what tyre compounds they will have chosen. In this heat, you'd anticipate a soft would be a stretch.
2023-10-07T17:23:15Z: In what could be his last F1 race weekend for a little while, with Daniel Ricciardo expected back soon, Liam Lawson lines up 14th for AlphaTauri ahead of Zhou Guanyu and Lance Stroll. Alex Albon, Yuki Tsunoda, Kevin Magnussen and Logan Sargeant round out the grid.
2023-10-07T17:21:37Z: Hamilton won the inaugural Qatar Grand Prix in 2021, but he'll face a tough ask to get among the sharp end in the sprint from 12th after he too fell victim to a track limits infringement. At least the Mercedes racer has got a crumb of familiarity from 2021 to hold onto tonight, as his old team-mate Bottas starts alongside him for Alfa Romeo.
2023-10-07T17:20:30Z: Behind the all-McLaren front row of Piastri and Norris, Verstappen and Russell share row two ahead of the Ferraris of Sainz and Leclerc. Then it's Hulkenberg, who beats Perez to seventh, while Alonso was a high profile victim of track limits in qualifying and will start ninth ahead of Alpine team-mates Ocon and Gasly.
2023-10-07T17:18:44Z: Drivers are starting to get their helmets on as we build up towards the sprint race getting going.
2023-10-07T17:17:42Z: For those weather fans among you, air temperatures are 31.9 °C while track temperatures stand at 36.0 °C. Chance of rain, as you'd expect, is non-existent.
2023-10-07T17:16:45Z: Now that we've got all of that preamble about tyres out of the way, who do we think will be making an impression in the sprint? At least after all of the talk about track limits during qualifying (which saw both McLarens docked their best times in Q3) and the sprint shootout, the focus on that will be reduced somewhat. We daren't say completely though...
2023-10-07T17:15:14Z: F1 has been in something of a luxury position in recent times where it hasn't had to worry too much about tyres becoming a source of problems, as it was infamously during the build-up to the 2005 US Grand Prix at Indianapolis. Here's how Pirelli discovered F1's biggest tyre drama since that fateful day when just six cars took the start: https://www.autosport.com/f1/news/how-pirelli-discovered-f1s-biggest-tyre-drama-since-the-2005-us-gp/10529831/
2023-10-07T17:13:42Z: Pirelli has stated that the tyre separation problems only showed up under microscopic examination. The issue has only shown up in tyres that have completed more than 20 laps, so motorsport boss Mario Isola has said he is confident there will be no issues for the 19-lap sprint race.
2023-10-07T17:12:34Z: As a result, track limits at Turns 12-13 were revised and an extra 10-minute familiarisation session was held earlier today just before sprint shootout qualifying to allow drivers to get used to the new policing. Here are the key questions surrounding F1's Qatar GP tyre drama: https://www.autosport.com/f1/news/the-key-questions-surrounding-f1s-qatar-gp-tyre-drama/10529978/
2023-10-07T17:11:07Z: It was discovered by F1's tyre supplier that sidewalls were being damaged against the kerbs, with a statement issued by the FIA suggesting that this problem could lead to air loss if the tyres were used too much. It is thought that the problem was triggered by new kerbs introduced for this weekend which were not present for the last running of the Qatar GP in 2021.
2023-10-07T17:09:36Z: The cars are lined up on the grid under the floodlights in Losail. We've got this far without mentioning tyres, but they could prove a factor in the race after a bombshell announcement earlier from Pirelli.
2023-10-07T17:08:13Z: Will that knowledge impact at all the way Verstappen races this evening? Somehow, we doubt that very much. McLaren certainly can't count on Verstappen switching to cruise and collect mode.
2023-10-07T17:06:31Z: Of course, for either to win, it will mean they have to get the better of champion elect Max Verstappen. The Red Bull man starts third, with George Russell alongside. Just three points from the sprint race (which means finishing sixth or higher) will secure Verstappen his third world title.
2023-10-07T17:05:11Z: Neither Norris, nor Piastri has ever won a race in F1 before. But if either wins the sprint today, it won't actually register on the official wins tally. Norris has finished second on five occasions, while Piastri scored his first F1 podium with third last time out at Suzuka.
2023-10-07T17:03:31Z: McLaren's superb qualifying show has raised the prospect of one of the papaya cars crossing the finish line first for the first time since Monza 2021, when Daniel Ricciardo enjoyed comfortably his best day with the Woking team. In case you'd forgotten, that was on a sprint race weekend too.
2023-10-07T17:02:08Z: The Australian rookie will be joined on the front row by Lando Norris in a McLaren front row lockout. We believe the last time that happened was at the 2012 Brazilian Grand Prix, won by Jenson Button. Piastri was just 11 on that bonkers day in Interlagos when Sebastian Vettel claimed his third world title.
2023-10-07T17:00:49Z: Welcome back to Autosport's live text commentary of track action from Qatar. We're half an hour away from the start of the sprint race, with Oscar Piastri on pole.
2023-10-07T14:25:45Z: With that, we'll take a break ahead of the Qatar sprint race which, all things being well, will start at 6:30pm BST. We'll be back for the pre-sprint build-up and the potential crowning of the 2023 F1 world champion. Go well!
2023-10-07T14:20:45Z:
Here's the full Qatar GP sprint qualifying report: https://www.autosport.com/f1/news/f1-qatar-gp-piastri-beats-norris-to-sprint-pole-as-mclaren-sweeps-shootout/10529898/
    
Oscar Piastri, McLaren MCL60
Photo by: Mark Sutton
2023-10-07T14:17:26Z: That is McLaren's first front row lockout in F1 since the 2012 Brazilian GP. Granted, it is just for the sprint race rather than the full-fat grand prix, but let's ignore technicalities for the time being.
2023-10-07T14:14:44Z: Behind the top three, Russell beats both Ferraris to fourth, with Hulkenberg an impressive seventh for Haas ahead of Perez, Alonso and Ocon. In fact, neither Alonso or Ocon technically set a lap time in Q3 due to track limit woes.
2023-10-07T14:12:39Z: It appears all is well, Piastri will be on pole for the Qatar sprint race ahead of McLaren team-mate Norris with Verstappen in third. In terms of the world title picture, that's all good for the Red Bull driver who only needs to finish sixth or better in the sprint to seal the title.
2023-10-07T14:10:45Z: After being interviewed in 'third' yesterday before being dropped down the order, Piastri is gingerly celebrating his sprint pole. This is a bit like VAR ruling on a goal while the team celebrates.
2023-10-07T14:08:58Z: Here come the post-qualifying lap time deletions! Alonso loses his best Q3 lap and drops from fifth to ninth. Will there be any further drops like yesterday?
2023-10-07T14:07:58Z: Norris has also been noted for not following the maximum delta lap time... you know the rest. It'll all shake out post-qualifying.
2023-10-07T14:07:13Z: After misery for McLaren in Q3 yesterday, with both drivers losing their best laps to track limits, it is double delight for the Woking team today with a front row lockout.
2023-10-07T14:05:58Z: Piastri is on pole for the Qatar GP! He puts in a 1m24.454s to move ahead of Norris and the Brit fails to reply as he goes wide at the final corner. McLaren 1-2!
2023-10-07T14:04:39Z: Verstappen goes third with a 1m24.646s - he cannot beat either McLaren!
2023-10-07T14:04:12Z: Russell goes third, three-tenths off the McLarens, as Perez gets a lap time deleted so cannot improve.
2023-10-07T14:02:29Z: Here come the McLarens! Piastri goes top for a few seconds before Norris puts in a 1m24.536s! Meanwhile Leclerc gets another lap time deleted. Two minutes to go, it is all or nothing now.
2023-10-07T14:01:28Z: Perez beats Sainz with a 1m25.382s. Leclerc also had his first Q3 lap time deleted for track limits but he backed out of that lap knowing his fate.
2023-10-07T14:00:13Z: It turns out, Verstappen can beat himself, as his lap time is deleted for exceeding track limits at Turn 5. So Sainz moves on to provisional pole.
2023-10-07T13:59:31Z: Verstappen sets the provisional pole time of 1m24.543s. Can anyone beat that?
2023-10-07T13:58:21Z: Perez also nips out, as the other six Q3 contenders stay in the pits focused on a one-and-down approach.
2023-10-07T13:56:39Z: Verstappen heads out, joined by both Ferrari drivers as the trio of early runners.
2023-10-07T13:55:50Z: Q3 sprint shootout time, an eight-minute blast to decide the top 10. Verstappen is all on his own sitting at pitlane exit waiting for the session to start.
2023-10-07T13:54:15Z: There are no further late lap time deletions, so the top 10 shootout is set. But the maximum delta time issue pops up once again, this time Russell and Gasly have been noted about it.
2023-10-07T13:51:30Z: Out in Q2: P11 Gasly, P12 Hamilton, P13 Bottas, P14 Lawson, P15 Zhou.
2023-10-07T13:51:04Z: Hulkenberg makes his last lap count as he jumps to ninth and that pushes Gasly out in 11th.
2023-10-07T13:50:24Z: And Sainz knocks out Hamilton, as the Ferrari driver goes seventh to push Hamilton to 11th.
2023-10-07T13:49:47Z: Hamilton gets his final lap time deleted so he drops to 10th and right on the edge of dropping out.
2023-10-07T13:49:08Z: The top two of Norris and Verstappen are in the pits confident of their progression. The rest are on their final laps in Q2 so it is now or never.
2023-10-07T13:47:40Z: Sainz gets his lap time deleted which pushes him back down to 13th. Is a double Q2 exit on for the Spaniard?
2023-10-07T13:47:02Z: The Ferrari pair both jump out of the Q2 drop zone, Leclerc up to fourth, but Sainz is on the bubble in 10th with two minutes to go.
2023-10-07T13:44:22Z: Norris pushes Verstappen off top spot with a 1m24.947s. Everyone is on mediums for this session, so that's a handy lap from the McLaren driver.
2023-10-07T13:43:34Z: Verstappen, who else, leads the early runners with a 1m25.199s while Hamilton and Leclerc get their first lap time deleted for, you guessed it, track limits.
2023-10-07T13:42:25Z: Already into the final seven minutes of Q2, that's how quick these sessions zip by, but five drivers are still yet to leave the pits.
2023-10-07T13:39:56Z: Anyway, off we go with Q2. Russell leads out the pack from Hamilton and Sainz.
2023-10-07T13:39:13Z: Hamilton, Gasly, Lawson, Sargeant, Tsunoda, Stroll and Albon are all in the dock this time around, with the incidents to be investigated after qualifying.
2023-10-07T13:38:25Z: The FIA stewards are also busy with drivers failing to follow the maximum delta lap time. This was also a feature of Friday qualifying, but everyone avoided a penalty due to it being triggered by drivers trying to avoid blocking others on quick laps.
2023-10-07T13:36:49Z: By our reckoning, everyone who dropped out in Q1 lost a personal best due to track limits. Sargeant lost all of his representative laps, which is why his 'best' was over 30s off the rest.
2023-10-07T13:34:50Z: Track limit pings coming thick and fast, and the final order to drop out in Q1 is: P16 Stroll, P17 Albon, P18 Tsunoda, P19 Magnussen, P20 Sargeant.
2023-10-07T13:33:36Z: No! Leclerc and then Tsunoda improve to push Sargeant out.
2023-10-07T13:33:03Z: Russell goes quickest overall as team-mate Hamilton improves to ninth. Sargeant lifts himself out of the drop zone to 15th but can he hang on?
2023-10-07T13:32:20Z: Zhou jumps out of the drop zone into 12th and pushes Leclerc into danger in 16th.
2023-10-07T13:31:41Z: Right, final lap time for Q1. It appears the danger areas are Turn 5 with the wind blowing cars off the track and Turn 13 a few drivers aren't totally dialled in to the track changes.
2023-10-07T13:30:15Z: Hamilton and Zhou are the next to get lap times deleted for track limits at Turn 13. Hamilton drops to 11th, Zhou last with no lap time to his name.
2023-10-07T13:29:17Z: The next flurry of laps tick by and Norris goes second from Russell, Hamilton and Piastri. The bottom five in danger are Magnussen, Lawson, Stroll, Sargeant and Zhou.
2023-10-07T13:28:17Z: Verstappen, as is customary, goes fastest with a 1m25.510s, while Gasly, who had jumped to second, drops down as he has a lap time deleted for track limits at Turn 13. Did he not learn anything from that 10-minute session.
2023-10-07T13:26:49Z: All the drivers are now on the track with just under six minutes to go in Q1. Hulkenberg and Sargeant have had lap times deleted for track limits.
2023-10-07T13:26:05Z: Russell's answer to his earlier question is definitely to get on with it, as he shoots to the top of the times with a 1m26.359s.
2023-10-07T13:25:03Z: The first lap times are coming in, with Norris the early leader with a 1m 26.464s. Still no sign of Alonso, Albon, Magnussen or the two Alfa Romeo drivers.
2023-10-07T13:24:14Z: Russell asks his Mercedes squad if he needs to do a preparation lap or get straight on with it following his out-lap. The reply is the team is still discussing. There's only eight minutes left of the session, not much time to overthink it.
2023-10-07T13:21:32Z: The Ferrari pair break the silence as Sainz leads out Leclerc, both on mediums, followed by Perez, Norris and Stroll.
2023-10-07T13:20:15Z: With everybody ready, let's begin. Sprint qualifying is go!
2023-10-07T13:18:18Z: Anyway, onwards. Sprint qualifying Q1 starts in a couple of minutes and is a 12-minute shootout to knock out the bottom five drivers.
2023-10-07T13:17:25Z: One of this year's sprint race format tweaks was to do away with the pointless Saturday practice session, but it came back with a 10-minute vengeance today. Hello, old friend.
2023-10-07T13:13:12Z: Verstappen finds just enough time to go off and skip over the gravel at Turn 5 before the end of the session. Red Bull may fret over his car floor given they've got under 10 minutes until the start of quali.
2023-10-07T13:11:56Z: That's it for this session, the sprint warm-up is a success but I doubt it'll catch on. Verstappen tops it from Leclerc by nearly two-tenths of a second.
2023-10-07T13:09:54Z: Gasly locks up into the Turn 6 hairpin and has to take to the run-off. No problems with the kerbs over there, Pierre, but thanks for checking.
2023-10-07T13:08:39Z: Verstappen leads the session with a 1m27.085s, half a second up on nearest challenger Zhou. Not that it really matters at this stage.
2023-10-07T13:06:56Z: Verstappen is definitely one that has gone wide at Turn 12-13, while at Turn 5 Sargeant takes out the 150m brake marker board with his Williams.
2023-10-07T13:05:52Z: All appears to be going to plan so far. But given the track limit detector doesn't kick in until sprint qualifying, it isn't so easy to pick out exactly who hasn't gelled with the track limit changes.
2023-10-07T13:02:06Z: Magnussen leads the pack out and the majority of drivers are on a used set of soft tyres. Lap times are largely irrelevant for this session, but it is a kind of non-competitive pre-qualifying.
2023-10-07T13:00:02Z: As expected, the entire F1 pack heads out to make the most of this short, sharp session.
2023-10-07T12:58:29Z: So, coming up is an unexpected 10-minute blast around the altered Qatar track, then a 10-minute pause before the start of sprint qualifying. After that normal service is resumed.
2023-10-07T12:55:22Z:
Further rule tweaks could follow for Sunday's race which would prevent a set of tyres being used for more than 20 racing laps. That'd mean all drivers needing a three-stop race. A final call will come after Pirelli and the FIA assess the situation following today's action.Here's the full story: https://www.autosport.com/f1/news/f1-introduces-emergency-safety-measures-for-qatar-gp-amid-tyre-failure-concerns-/10529811/
    
Qatar pyramid kerbs
Photo by: Alex Kalinauckas
2023-10-07T12:53:53Z: Pirelli, together with the FIA, have acted on safety grounds, by changing the track limits at Turn 12-13 where the new kerbs are most prominent. A 10-minute familiarisation track session will take place now to get the drivers up to speed on the tweaks.
2023-10-07T12:50:36Z: Starting at the beginning, naturally, a Pirelli tyre issue was picked up late last night when its engineers inspected the used tyres from Friday. There was sidewall damage to the tyres which was triggered by the new kerbs in Qatar.
2023-10-07T12:47:54Z: Hello one and all! Will Verstappen be crowned 2023 F1 world champion today? It is very likely, but we have a few things to get through before then, starting with tyre talk...
